David King is currently a commentator fo.page_content:
Controversy surrounded Saturday night’s Showdown – but not because of anything that happened on the field.

Fox Footy has come under fire for broadcasting the game from their Victorian studio, rather than being at the ground, while the voting panel has been criticised for awarding the Showdown Medal to Jordan Dawson.

Izak Rankine kicked four goals and Riley Thilthorpe kicked five, but the pair didn’t feature in the top three of the voting.

Speaking first on Fox Footy’s decision to broadcast the Showdown from Victoria, King says, while it’s unfortunate, the commentators actually have just as much if not more to work with from the studio than live at Adelaide Oval.

“Can we give a bit of background on this? Because I’m getting crushed for not being there (at the ground),” King told SEN’s Whateley.

“The flippant discussion that we watch the game off a TV screen couldn’t be further from the truth. Unfortunately for a whole host of reasons we’re calling from the studios. Not going to get involved in that.

“We can see everything. We can see the whole field. We’ve got a wall of screens. I’ve got the ability to look behind the ball, forward of the ball, wherever your eyes go on game day, it’s the same except it’s on a wall screen.

“To say we’re missing things is wrong. You can see whatever you need to see and I have no problem with that and then combining that and the feel of the game and seeing player impact.

“Then we have the screen that people see at home and the end product, which is the main screen we look at. When you first go into television, the bosses say just call and talk about things people can see. There’s no point talking about what’s behind the ball if people can’t see it.

“If you’re statistically minded like I am, I’ve got a more detailed statistical setup than the average person has at the game, I’d in fact mount a case that I’ve got more information than those at the ground because that’s real.

“Now, I don’t hear the crowd roar. And I don’t get to see who wins the toss from time to time … all those sorts of things, to me it’s not really an impact for assessing a game.

“I understand why people are put out by us not being there from time to time or regularly, but I don’t get the rationale that we don’t see the ground because that is 100 per cent wrong.

“Does it impact cricket? I think it does, but I don’t think it impacts footy.”

King gave Rankine three votes for his four-goal effort in the Showdown, but was the only one on the panel who gave the forward a vote.

Scott Camporeale, Simeon Thomas-Wilson, Josh Francou and Rhett Biglands all included Dawson in their votes, with King preferring Rankine, Rory Laird and Connor Rozee.

Laird was impactful for the Crows with 11 clearances, while Rozee finished with 28 and a goal.

Dawson won the medal with nine votes, from Reilly O’Brien with six and Rozee at three.

“When I saw the other votes I had this sick feeling and thought ‘have I got this totally wrong here’. You straight away think ‘someone’s in trouble here’. I was hoping it wasn’t me!” King said.

“A guy kicked five and I didn’t give him a vote, that’s probably the main feedback I’m getting.

“I assessed Rankine’s impact as greater than anyone on the ground. I gave him three. I was the only one to give him a vote. And Laird.

“Rankine had the biggest moments. You could’ve mounted a case for three or four players, but in the end you track back to what you value and when the game was in the arm wrestle, he was the reason why the Crows scored and the reason why they still had belief and the magic.

“Thilthorpe was very good. If Laird wasn’t there, he had 11 clearances for the day, they got smacked at clearances by Port, if he wasn’t having a clearance impact it would’ve been an avalanche to one end of the ground and Port would’ve found a way to win.

“I thought Rozee was significant in the first three quarters of the game. Halfway through the last quarter Port was in front so the 30-point margin wasn’t reflective of the game.

“Am happy not to do the voting again. It’s just not worth the feedback.”

King said he went home and watched the game again just to make sure of his votes!

“I saw the votes come through ahead of time and Dawson was in all the votes and Rankine wasn’t and I thought oh wow. I was nervous that I’d got it wrong,” he said.

“I knew what the numbers were saying and what my eyes were saying.

“I actually went home and watched the game again. I can’t believe I did that, but I needed to appease myself.

“In the end it was a great game of footy and it’s a shame we’re talking about the votes and not what these young men were able to do.”

David King‘s source of wealth comes from being a australian rules footballer. How much money is David King worth at the age of 51 and what’s his real net worth now?

As of 2023, David King’s net worth is $100,000 - $1M.

DETAILS BELOW

David King (born March 7, 1972) is famous for being australian rules footballer. He currently resides in Australia. Former Australian Rules Football player who won the AFL premiership title in 1996 and 1999 while playing with North Melbourne. After his playing days, he started working for Fox Footy and SEN 1116 as an announcer.

David King is a Pisces and was born in The Year of the Rat

Life

David King was born in Australia on Tuesday, March 7, 1972 (Generation X). He is 51 years old and is a Pisces. He earned All-Australian honors twice during his playing days. He’s also worked as an assistant coach for Richmond.

He played for Port Melbourne before joining North Melbourne in 1994. He played with them until his retirement in 2004, kicking 145 goals in 241 games with the club. The education details are not available at this time. Please check back soon for updates. David King is a member of Richest Celebrities and Australian Rules Footballers.

After a record-breaking pre-season, Foxtel today unveiled FOX FOOTY’s full expert team, show and game day coverage, including every game of every round, plus all finals games leading into the Grand Final, LIVE in HD and ad-break free during play.

Carlton superstar Eddie Betts will make his move into game day commentary on the dedicated AFL channel and Melbourne gun Christian Petracca joins the AFL 360 team alongside Jack Riewoldt, Adam Treloar and Betts for Players Night.

“When I started playing AFL footy I hated talking to the media. Going to FOX FOOTY is like going back to school with the big dogs like Jonathan Brown and Nick Riewoldt,” said Betts.

Hosted by Garry Lyon, Sarah Jones, Kelli Underwood and Kath Loughnan FOX FOOTY’S weekend of live action begins before the first siren sounds every round and continues until the locker rooms are empty on a Sunday.

Every coach will again join Gerard Whateley and Mark Robinson and the AFL 360 team on Monday nights ahead of a huge week of big name guests.

On The Couch celebrates its twentieth year on air with original host Gerard Healy still at the helm. He is joined by the biggest names in the game, Lyon, Jonathan Brown and Nick Riewoldt.

Dermott Brereton will host new show Dermie Delivers – a weekly look back at two of the biggest stars and their best games.

The First Crack will beat everyone else to the finish line on Thursdays and Fridays after the game and on Sundays after Bounce. The revolving panel of FOX FOOTY experts will offer fans their first fix on all games and stories.

Anthony Hudson, David King and Brereton will begin the biggest day of footy with Saturday Countdown.

Saturday Stretch after Saturday Footy on FOX will round out the night for footy fans. Loughnan, Brad Johnson, Jordan Lewis and Tom Morris will provide the best wrap of the day.

Bounce host Jason Dunstall will wrangle the loose Andrew Gaze, Cameron Mooney, Sharni Norder and Bernie Vince as they make the whole family laugh on Sunday nights.

FOX FOOTY and Kayo will for the first time ever also offer game day Minis for all nine games. The shortened version of the match allows fans to catch up on all the action and highlights in less than 20 minutes.

“FOX FOOTY is back with all our shows, including AFL 360, and we are incredibly pleased to have Eddie Betts and Christian Petracca join our line-up. We have a commentary and production team that’s the best in the business, and with no ad-breaks during play, fans know that FOX FOOTY is the go-to place for all the 2021 season football action,” FOX SPORTS Executive Director Steve Crawley said.

FOX FOOTY’s unrivalled commentary team includes the biggest names in the business: Adam Papalia, Adam Treloar, Alastair Lynch, Andrew Gaze, Anthony Hudson, Ben Dixon, Bernie Vince, Brad Johnson, Brenton Speed, Cameron Mooney, Christian Petracca, David King, Dermott Brereton, Dwayne Russell, Eddie Betts, Garry Lyon, Gerard Healy, Gerard Whateley, Jack Riewoldt, Jason Dunstall, Jon Ralph, Jonathan Brown, Jordan Lewis, Katherine Loughnan, Kelli Underwood, Leigh Montagna, Mark Ricciuto, Mark Robinson, Mike Sheahan, Nick Dal Santo, Nick Riewoldt, Sarah Jones, Sharni Norder, Tom Morris

About David

David King is a former North Melbourne AFL duel Premiership player. He debuted for the Kangaroos in 1994 after being recruited from Port Melbourne at the age of 22. He went on to play 241 games and kicked 145 goals, winning premierships in 1996 and 1999.

He is notable for holding a AFL record by playing in Preliminary Finals for seven consecutive years from his debut year in 1994 to 2000.He was twice an AFL All Australian and retired at the end of the 2004 season. He then joined the Richmond Football Club as an assistant coach in 2005.

He is currently a commentator for Fox Footy and SEN Radio. He won the Most Outstanding Television Special Comments award at the 2012 AFL Media Awards.

You can cite plenty of problems Geelong’s winless start, but their bizarre gambling tactics have to be addressed.

Plus the growing proof Carlton’s fast start is for real, the years-long Adelaide flaw and much more.

Every club’s burning question ahead of Round 3, as well as commentators for every Fox Footy game in our ultimate weekly preview: The Blowtorch!

Watch every blockbuster AFL match this weekend Live & Ad-Break Free In-Play on Kayo. New to Kayo? Start your free trial now >

AFL ROUND 3 FIXTURE (All times AEDT)

WESTERN BULLDOGS v BRISBANE LIONS

Thursday March 30, 7:20pm at Marvel Stadium

How to watch on Fox Footy: Channel 504 from 6.30pm, hosted by Sarah Jones with Jason Dunstall, David King, Leigh Montagna, Brad Johnson and Jon Ralph.

Bulldogs’ burning question: Where does the fight come from?

The Western Bulldogs have been a surprise packet in 2023 – and not in a good way. Their highly-vaunted midfield has been labelled “inept” by Fox Footy’s David King after two rounds and a “real concern” for coach Luke Beveridge given his side “can’t win the ball”. The Dogs were smashed through the middle by St Kilda last weekend, finishing -13 in ground ball gets and -13 in tackles in just the first quarter alone. “Some of these efforts were just really surprising. Blokes taking their eyes off the footy, just fumbling and being jittery,” Fox Footy’s Leigh Montagna said. “For some reason I’m not sure why they are bereft of confidence.”

Lions’ burning question: Who provides the spark outside of Dayne Zorko?

Brisbane looked out of sorts against Port Adelaide in Round 1, as they were essentially smashed in every facet of the game. Enter Round 2 and the return of former skipper Dayne Zorko. Despite as the Lions’ “angry ant” by Nathan Buckley, Zorko provided an immediate spark as he slotted a first quarter goal and provided plenty of run through the middle. “He’s been the spirit of this club for a long time. The ex-captain, five-time best and fairest winner, he brings a spark and an energy that the Lions didn’t have last week,” Jonathan Brown praised. But with Zorko 34, the question needs to be asked – who will step up to the mantle in Zorko’s absence? Lachie Neale already carries a heavy burden as the club’s premier mid, while Harris Andrews is deep in defence and not able to get involved across the ground. Coach Chris Fagan needs to find his next spark.

COLLINGWOOD v RICHMOND

Friday March 31, 7:50pm at the MCG

How to watch on Fox Footy: Channel 504 from 7pm, with Garry Lyon, Jonathan Brown, Nathan Buckley, Jordan Lewis, Kath Loughnan and Jon Ralph, followed by Fox Footy Live with Drew Jones, Cameron Mooney and Nick Dal Santo.

Magpies’ burning question: Who can stop the ‘Flagpies’ run?

Craig McRae and his band of merry men are simply dominating after two rounds of AFL action. The Magpies have shown their preliminary final run was no fluke as the team has improved exponentially in areas that held them back last season. After being ranked 17th in contested differential, Collingwood is now sitting first. Statistics show the Magpies are ranked No. 1 for ball movement, second for ball use and third for contest and clearance in warning signs for their rivals. “Their first two rounds were amazing. Offensive weapons everywhere and a style of play making the most of what they’ve got,” Fox Footy’s Nathan Buckley said. “We love the way they play – it’s exciting. (McRae’s) come in clearly and given them confidence to just pull the trigger,” Jonathan Brown added on On the Couch.

Tigers’ burning question: Is it the former skipper to the rescue for Richmond?

No Dustin Martin and no Jacob Hopper for Richmond this week leaves the side “thread bare” according to Gerard Whateley and undermanned in the middle. But veteran Trent Cotchin looms as Richmond’s potential saviour. The former skipper can rotate through the middle, and four-time premiership player Luke Hodge believes there’s an even bigger role with Cotchin’s name on it – shutting down Nick Daicos. “(Play) as a defensive forward this week,” he said on SEN. “There’s a smart bloke who’s disciplined and who knows how to find the footy. (Cotchin) can play a serious role for them. All he has to do is limit (Daicos) to 12,13, 15 touches and if Cotch kicks a goal, they’d look at that as an even. There’s a role for him – limit (Collingwood’s) most attacking, best kick in the game and see if you can add value that way to the side.” Fox Footy commentator Gerard Healy agreed that a defensive forward role has worked against Daicos in the past, pointing to Swan Ryan Clarke.

HAWTHORN v NORTH MELBOURNE

Saturday April 1, 1:45pm at UTAS, Tasmania

How to watch on Fox Footy: Channel 504 from 1.30pm, with Mark Howard, Kelli Underwood, Dermott Brereton, Nick Dal Santo and Ben Dixon.

Hawks’ burning question: Are Hawthorn fighting too many battles?

Off field drama and on field obstacles … The once-mighty Hawthorn has turned into a shambles in 2023 with questions asked over whether the club cut too harshly at the end of last season. Some even accused the club of a form of tanking, given how far they’ve fallen. Sitting anchored at the bottom of the table with the worst attack (averaging 51 points per game) and worst defensive end (coughing up an average 121 points), Fox Footy’s Mark Robinson warns “on every front, they are a mess”. “They’ve made this decision – no one is coaching this team to a lot of victories this year so everyone has got to chill out a little bit,” he said on AFL 360. “I said … ‘settle down Hawks fans, you’ve dominated the comp for a decade, now you know what it’s like’. But you’ve got to have trust. You’ve got have faith.”





Kangaroos’ burning question: How much has the Perth trip taken out of them?

North Melbourne are riding high off of back-to-back wins to open the season – but how much of a toll has those wins taken? The trip to Perth is the most brutal in the competition; add on the fact the Roos are now off to Tasmania and the kilometres are really starting to add up. “North Melbourne have had two really good wins, over in the west it’s always hard to travel back and go down to Tasmania and travel down there,” he said on AFL 360. On top of the physical toll is the mental side to the game. The Roos escaped with a thrilling dying second victory over Fremantle in emotional scenes on the sidelines from payers and staff alike including coach Alastair Clarkson. Now they have to get their heads back in the game against a Hawthorn side who are “backs against the wall” – it’s no easy feat.

GWS GIANTS v CARLTON

Saturday April 1, 4:35pm at GIANTS Stadium

How to watch on Fox Footy: Channel 504 from 4.30pm, with Anthony Hudson, Garry Lyon, Jason Dunstall and Alastair Lynch.

Giants’ burning question: How long can GWS run on ‘Greene energy’?

GWS captain Toby Greene has certainly proved the firestarter for his side in the opening two rounds. He’s kicked two bags of four goals, averaging 18.5 disposals per game. Fox Footy’s Gerard Whateley questioned how long the club can rely on “Greene energy” in season 2023. Richmond forward Jack Riewoldt was full of praise for his rival: “Undersized forwards are the hardest forwards to match up on,” he said. “(He’s) a smoky for the Coleman. Toby just don’t get suspended.” Despite missing the first five games of 2022 due to suspension, Greene still finished with 37 goals to his name – going goalless just once in the 15 matches he played. He hit the scoreboard every match he played in 2021 – meaning he’s now kicked goals in 35 of his past 36 matches.

Blues’ burning question: Have we already seen the proof they’ve changed for the better?

Clearly the Blues’ start has been promising – they’re unbeaten through two rounds, with five games against teams that finished below them on the ladder in 2022 over the next five rounds. But the underlying numbers look even better. Last year, powered by Brownlow medallist Patrick Cripps, they were a team reliant on contested footy. With Sam Walsh and George Hewett on the injury list, they’ve been unable to focus on that source – which is good because scoring from turnover is much more reliable. This year the Blues’ points differential is +19 from turnovers (it was +0.6 last year), and -11.5 from clearances (+8.5 last year). So they’re scoring the same amount overall, but from a much better source – and they should only get better at clearances once they’re at full strength.

ST KILDA v ESSENDON

Saturday April 1, 7:25pm at the MCG

How to watch on Fox Footy: Channel 504 from 7.15pm with Kath Loughnan, Brad Johnson and Jonathan Brown.

Saints’ burning question: Can the ‘no name’ St Kilda forwards get the job done?

Fox Footy’s Nathan Buckley may have labelled St Kilda’s attack end as “no names”, but not in a bad way. With Max King and Tim Membrey, they were “so effective” in attack last year as they reached 8-3. But with those two sidelined, the Saints have uncovered a few gems including Anthony Caminiti. Caminiti’s journey to the AFL is bizarre, after he impressed Jack Silvagni at Carlton training. Silvagni’s dad Steve swooped and landed Caminiti at St Kilda. “Caminiti is the one who’s just come from nowhere,” Gerard Healy praised on SEN. “Once Steve Silvagni moves out of the talent ID, his son should move right in. (Caminiti) was superb again and looked dangerous.”

Bombers’ burning question: Can they continue their defensive gut run?

Under new coach Brad Scott, Essendon are opting to run and carry the ball at every opportunity. The Bombers are taking the game on in fantastic signs for the club’s development, Fox Footy’s Leigh Montagna believes. “This is what I love now, this defensive intent,” he said on First Crack. “They would turn the ball over and use their talent, their run and carry to challenge them going back the other way. Gold Coast just couldn’t go with them.” Last week Essendon were ranked number one in the competition for metres gained by handball. In remarkable improvement on their 2022 efforts, the Bombers were also ranked fourth for pressure (up from 18th in 2022), third for tackles (up from 17th) and fourth in points off turnover differential – compared to 16th last season. The question now is – can they sustain it?

PORT ADELAIDE v ADELAIDE CROWS

Saturday April 1, 7:30pm at Adelaide Oval

How to watch on Fox Footy: Channel 503 from 7.25pm, with Dwayne Russell, Gerard Healy, David King and Mark Ricciuto.

Power’s burning question: Which Port Adelaide will turn up for the Showdown?

After two rounds, it’s like watching Jekyll and Hyde when it comes to the Power after a brilliant win over Brisbane and a shambolic loss to Collingwood in the space of seven days. In Round 1, Port Adelaide were unstoppable, precise and completely dominant through the middle of the ground as their young mids dismantled the Lions. But against the Magpies, the Power looked lost, uncertain and unable to win the tough ball. In contrast, the Power claimed 150 contested possessions in Rd 1, compared to just 98 against the Pies – a turnaround of -52! There was a -20 clearance differential between the two matches and -14 marks inside 50. The efficiency going into attack sat at just 42.6% in Rd 2 – down a whopping 18% on Rd 1. So which Port Adelaide turns up for the Showdown? Ken Hinkley will be hoping it’s the Round 1 version.

Crows’ burning question: Is the much-praised forward line actually the problem?

The Crows don’t appear to be lacking for talent in the front six with Izak Rankine joining the likes of Tex Walker, Darcy Fogarty and Josh Rachele, but for a fourth straight year Matthew Nicks’ men are proving wasteful in front of goal. Numbers from the Pure Footy show revealed only Sydney and Collingwood have had more shots at goal this year, but Adelaide ranks 15th in the AFL for Champion Data’s shot at goal rating. That comes after they ranked 18th in 2020, 16th in 2021 and 10th last year. Goalkicking arguably determined last Saturday’s loss to Richmond – the actual score was 76-108, but the expected score was 86-91, suggesting the Crows were bad at converting in front of goal and the Tigers were very good. This appears to be a long-term issue; though at least they’re creating chances.





GOLD COAST SUNS v GEELONG

Sunday April 2, 2:10pm at Heritage Bank Stadium

How to watch on Fox Footy: Channel 504 from 2pm, with Anthony Hudson, Dermott Brereton, Cam Mooney, Alastair Lynch and Sarah Jones.

Suns’ burning question: Does Gold Coast coach Stuart Dew take a stand at selection?

Fox Footy’s David King did not hold back in his assessment on the efforts of two Gold Coast players in the loss to Essendon. King highlighted plays from key-position duo Charlie Ballard and Jack Lukosius for particular scrutiny, claiming teammates should be “fuming” for their “unacceptable” plays. Big forward Mabior Chol was dropped last weekend – does Stuart Dew swing the axe again in their 0-2 start? “I’m in awe of the effort, attitude and application of Touk Miller, Matt Rowell, Noah Anderson, the big ruckman (Jarrod) Wicks, Nick Holman, Sam Collins; guys who maybe aren’t front liners but play with everything they’ve got,” King said on First Crack. “I watched Miller push himself, I watched Rowell go to the absolute extremes. Take a stand Gold Coast. Shift the course of your culture and not just drop guys because it’s a name … drop them because of the effort they are providing.”

Cats’ burning question: Are they taking too many risks?

While Collingwood has been lauded for its brave ball movement, it‘s actually Geelong taking the most chances by foot. Champion Data analyst Daniel Hoyne told Pure Footy the Cats’ expected hit rate on their kicks this season, based on a 10-year AFL average of how many of those kicks have been made, is just 40 per cent. For context, the risky Pies’ expected hit rate is 48 per cent, and last year the Cats’ rate was 52 per cent. But the premiers aren’t getting scoreboard return from these risks either – they’re coughing up a horrendous 70.5 points per game from turnover, more than double last year’s figure. They’ve given up six goals a game from “giveaways” – when they gift the ball straight back to the opposition, rather than having it taken away. If this is a tactic by Chris Scott, it is absolutely not working.



MELBOURNE v SYDNEY SWANS

Sunday April 2, 3:20pm at the MCG

How to watch on Fox Footy: Channel 503 from 3pm, hosted by Sarah Jones with Jordan Lewis and Eddie Betts.

Demons’ burning question: Will Brodie Grundy be the ruck leader Melbourne need?

Brodie Grundy was at the top of his game at the start of 2022, having signed a big money deal to essentially become a Magpie for life. But injury and then a bombshell trade to Melbourne to free up salary cap space at Collingwood ensured Grundy’s career looked a lot different to start 2023. Now with Demons skipper Max Gawn’s knee injury, there’s a big opportunity for Grundy to take Melbourne’s ruck mantle. Statistics show Grundy is ranked currently eighth for total hitouts but sits last for hit outs to advantage of the 25 ruckmen in the competition – with 0 scores coming from his hitouts. “Does he play the Max Gawn role that has worked so well for Melbourne,” Fox Footy’s Leigh Montagna questioned. “Or do what we saw at Collingwood where he hovered in the corridor? They want him to get long down the line.” David King said he doesn’t think Grundy “can cover the ground” to emulate the feats of Gawn. “Just watching pre-season, he’s miles off where Max is at,” King added.

Swans’ burning question: Do Sydney still need Buddy Franklin?

Just last week we put the Blowtorch on youngster Logan McDonald to see if his form without Lance Franklin could continue. And he kicked five goals in response. “Where does it leave Buddy in terms of the overall?” On the Couch’s Garry Lyon said. “I reckon if there’s one club that looks past names for instance and just chooses who its best side is, it’s Sydney. That’s the way Sydney goes about it,” Nathan Buckley replied. Statistics show the Swans are averaging 90.4 points with Franklin and 99.4 points without him. But Buckley believes Franklin has the aerobic capacity to play a Jeremy Cameron-like role to get up the ground and turn for attack. “I think he’s got a spot,” Buckley added.

FREMANTLE v WEST COAST EAGLES

Sunday April 2, 5:20pm at Optus Stadium

How to watch on Fox Footy: Channel 504 from 5pm, with Adam Papalia, Dwayne Russell, Gerard Healy, Matthew Pavlich, Will Schofield and Kath Loughnan.

Dockers’ burning question: Where do the goals come from?

It’s deja vu for Fremantle as forward line woes continue to hurt the winless Dockers. Nat Fyfe was missing from that attack end in Round 2 while Matt Taberner has been well below par – subbed out from both matches by three quarter time. The Dockers have the third-worst forward line in the competition after two rounds – behind Hawthorn and the Western Bulldogs. Fox Footy’s Nick Dal Santo believes the lack of goals stems from the lack of fast ball movement. “They are ‘Freeze-mantle’ at the moment,” he said on AFL Tonight. “They are frozen in the spot, they have no flair in their game. What they’ve put on the scoreboard at the moment ain’t going to get it done.”





Eagles’ burning question: Will West Coast keep running and taking the game on?

The Eagles have been poor at the contest for a number of seasons before they suddenly found their drive against GWS last weekend. West Coast finally won the inside 50, clearance and contested ball count in a single match in positive signs for coach Adam Simpson. The Eagles finished with their highest metres gained by handball since 2017, their highest kick forward percentage since 2021, the best ball movement stats since 2019 and the best ground ball differential since 2017. “They turned up on Sunday and played the sort of footy the modern game demands,” On the Couch host Garry Lyon said. “They were a bit outdated.” Fox Footy’s Nathan Buckley believes Simpson gave his players free reign to run and carry. “It might have been all in, ‘I don’t care about the mistakes we make on the two v ones or the little marks’,” he said.

DAVID KING

AFL FOOTBALLER & TELEVISION PERSONALITY

David King (born 7 March 1972) is a former Australian rules footballer who played for the North Melbourne Football Club in the Australian Football League (AFL). He debuted for the Kangaroos in 1994 after being recruited from Port Melbourne Football Club at the age of 22. He went on to play 241 games and kicked 145 goals, winning premierships in 1996 and 1999.

King represented Victoria in State of Origin on more than one occasion, including in 1998. David King is notable for holding a VFL/AFL record by playing in Preliminary Finals for seven consecutive years from his debut year in 1994 to 2000.

David King was twice an AFL All-Australian and retired at the end of the 2004 season. He then joined theRichmond Football Club as an assistant coach in 2005.

David King is currently a commentator for Fox Footy and SEN 1116. He won the Most Outstanding Television Special Comments award at the 2012 AFL Media Awards.

On February 19, 2015, Australian media reported that he was being investigated by police about successful bets he made predicting the winner of the 2014 AFL Rising Star award.

Wiki Link

About

Former Australian Rules Football player who won the AFL premiership title in 1996 and 1999 while playing with North Melbourne. After his playing days, he started working for Fox Footy and SEN 1116 as an announcer.

Before Fame

He played for Port Melbourne before joining North Melbourne in 1994. He played with them until his retirement in 2004, kicking 145 goals in 241 games with the club.

Trivia

He earned All-Australian honors twice during his playing days. He's also worked as an assistant coach for Richmond.

Family Life

He played for Victoria in the State of Origin.

Associated With

He and Wayne Carey were teammates on North Melbourne.

Twice named as an AFL All-Australian, multiple State of Origin representative and holder of an AFL/VFL record for playing in preliminary finals for 7 consecutive years, former North Melbourne player David King is an outspoken and at times controversial commentator who shoots from the hip.

David King debuted for the Kangaroos in 1994 after being recruited from Port Melbourne. He went on to play 241 games and kicked 145 goals, and was a member of the winning Premiership teams of 1996 and 1999.

A niggly in-your-face backman who liked to let the opposition know that he was around, King quickly gained a reputation for being fast and hard at the ball. He played most of his first season in the ones, however, didn’t really find his niche until 1996 when coach Denis Pagan shifted him from the wing to defence.

Notorious for his capacity to run 20-30 metres out of defence then fire a 60-metre torpedo, King’s dash and enthusiasm were vital ingredients for the Roo’s over many seasons.

King played every game in 2004, but his form fluctuated late in the year and he was often used off the bench. Although he probably could have squeezed out another season, he came to a consensus with the club that he would retire.

After retirement David held an assistant coaching position with the Richmond Football Club, he then moved into the media winning the Most Outstanding Television Special Comments award at the 2012 AFL Media Awards. He is currently seen on Fox Footy weekly in the AFL Season and calls the game for SEN1116.

Speaking with a passion he is as hard with his chat as he was with the ball when playing...and just like those playing days, he doesn’t fear the consequences when he does go in hard.

Fox Footy’s David King believes the AFL’s ‘hub’ idea could stretch far beyond just one month. Pic: Michael Klein

WATCH OUR NEW SHOW FOX FOOTY LIVE ON CHANNEL 504 FROM 5PM

Fox Footy analyst David King has revealed the idea of players spending ‘as much as 20 weeks’ playing in isolated hubs is being canvassed as an ‘extreme option’, as the AFL continues to develop the radical idea in an effort to get a season away in 2020 despite the coronavirus outbreak.

The idea of hubs is one of several scenarios the AFL are considering, but despite commentators such as Gerard Whateley labelling the idea “immoral”, King believes that not only is the idea being considered, but the length to which it’s implemented could be more drastic than a period of just a month or so.

“There’s a whole host of things being canvassed at the moment, but there’s options to basically play the complete season in isolation, that’s the extreme option, and then it’s watered down right down to two or three weeks,” King said on ﻿Fox Footy Live.

Watch Foxtel in an instant. Catch up and settle in with no installation & no lock-in contract. Sign up to all of Foxtel Now with a 10-day free trial. New customers only

AFL Players Association president Paul Marsh has said hub talks remain preliminary. Source: AAP

“It could be as much as, what I’m hearing, one option’s as much as 20 weeks.”

“I don’t know the exacts, I don’t know if it’s plus finals… but let’s just say 20 weeks is a negotiated starting point Dwayne (Russell), you know what it’s like… you start from different angles and you get to a point.”

Despite much of the playing fraternity expressing their desire to play footy again when safe, King said the game could resume even if a small percentage of players decided against committing to the idea.

“I do think if you’re not prepared to go, don’t go, I don’t think we’d have a problem if 10 players said (they wouldn’t go).

“...AFL will go on Dwayne, the game is bigger than any one name, so If we had 10 players pull out, I still think we’d push forward. If this was ticked off from a medical and health and safety point of view then I mean we’d move forward wouldn’t we? I mean, why would we stop? Because a percentage of players wouldn’t do it?”

King strongly believes that, above all else, the decision facing the players should be a health decision first, rather than a financial one.

“If you individually have a problem with potentially risking the health of your family upon return or whatever your issue is, no one’s twisting your arm, no one is saying you have to go,” he said.

“It’s a lifestyle decision, it’s a life decision it’s not a financial decision for me it’s a health decision first and then worry about the finances after that.”
